thread.title: Caldwell-Pope's three completes Pistons' rally past Raptors, 102-101
thread.title_full: Caldwell-Pope's three completes Pistons' rally past Raptors, 102-101

author: Detroit Free Press
title: Caldwell-Pope's three completes Pistons' rally past Raptors, 102-101
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Caldwell-Pope's three completes Pistons' rally past Raptors, 102-101 KCP scores final five points, as Pistons fight back to erase 16-point deficit entering 4th, move into tie for 7-seed Post to Facebook Caldwell-Pope's three completes Pistons' rally past Raptors, 102-101 KCP scores final five points, as Pistons fight back to erase 16-point deficit entering 4th, move into tie for 7-seed Check out this story on Freep.com: http://on.freep.com/2l5dhdf Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 8 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Caldwell-Pope's three completes Pistons' rally past Raptors, 102-101 Vince Ellis , Detroit Free Press Published 8:43 p.m. ET Feb. 12, 2017 | Updated 11 minutes ago CLOSE x Share Pistons coach Stan Van Gundy and Kentavious Caldwell-Pope discuss KCP's winning three-pointer to top the Raptors, 102-101, on Sunday, Feb. 12, 2017. Video by Vince Ellis, DFP. Videolicious KCP scores final five points, as Pistons fight back to erase 16-point deficit entering 4th, move into tie for 7-seed Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons guard Ish Smith drives to the basket over Raptors center Lucas Nogueira during the second quarter at Air Canada Centre. (Photo: Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports) 94 CONNECT 8 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TORONTO – Shooters shoot. 
Even when enduring a nightmarish 1-for-11 shooting night from three-point range. 
Detroit Pistons shooting guard Kentavious Caldwell-Pope was having such an evening Sunday at the Air Canada Center. 
But the previous 10 missed threes were quickly forgotten when his corner three-pointer with 13.2 seconds left proved to be the winning basket in a thrilling 102-101 comeback victory over the Toronto Raptors. 
Box score 
Marcus Morris forced a contested shot from Raptors star DeMar DeRozan in the closing seconds, and when center Andre Drummond pulled down his 18th rebound, the Pistons had completed the long road back from a 16-point deficit entering the fourth quarter. 
The final horn set off a wild celebration from the Pistons (26-29), who move into a tie for seventh place in the Eastern Conference. 
“Really excited about (the victory),” Pistons coach Stan Van Gundy said. “I’m not the most positive guy in the world sometimes, but the assistant coaches can vouch for this – even at the end of the third when we were down 16 and we were struggling, but I said to our assistants … our guys are playing hard, they’re fighting. 
“They fought and fought. It wasn’t easy, it wasn’t one those runs were you hit three of four threes in row. It was just grind it out, grind it out. Get it down to manageable number. Got a couple of big stops and a great shot down the stretch.” Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons forward Marcus Morris celebrates with Pistons guard Ish Smith (right) after defeating the Raptors, 102-101, at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Toronto Raptors guard Cory Joseph (6) controls a ball as Detroit Pistons guard Ish Smith (14) defends during the third quarter in a game at Air Canada Centre.The Detroit Pistons won 102-101. Mandatory Credit: Nick Turchiaro-USA TODAY Sports Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Detroit Pistons forward Tobias Harris (34) shoots a ball at the basket over Toronto Raptors guard Cory Joseph (6) during the first quarter in a game at Air Canada Centre.The Pistons won 102-101. Mandatory Credit: Nick Turchiaro-USA TODAY Sports Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Toronto Raptors guard Kyle Lowry (7) drives to the basket as Detroit Pistons guard Kentavious Caldwell-Pope (5) defends during the fourth quarter at Air Canada Centre. The Detroit Pistons won 102-101. Mandatory Credit: Nick Turchiaro-USA TODAY Sports Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Toronto Raptors guard DeMar DeRozan (10) argues with referee Leroy Richardson during second half NBA basketball action against the Detroit Pistons in Toronto on Sunday, Feb. 12, 2017. (Frank Gunn/The Canadian Press via AP) Frank Gunn, AP Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Raptors guard DeMar DeRozan shoots in the final seconds of the fourth quarter as Pistons forward Marcus Morris defends at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons guard Reggie Jackson drives to the basket as Raptors guard DeMar DeRozan defends during the first quarter at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Raptors guard DeMar DeRozan drives to the hoop against Pistons forward Tobias Harris during the second half in Toronto, Sunday, Feb.12, 2017. Frank Gunn, AP Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons head coach Stan Van Gundy reacts during the second quarter against the Raptors at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons head coach Stan Van Gundy reacts during the second quarter in a game against the Raptors at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons guard Ish Smith shoots over Raptors guard Cory Joseph during the first quarter at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons guard Ish Smith controls the ball as Raptors guard Norman Powell tries to defend during the second quarter at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Feb 12, 2017; Toronto, Ontario, CAN; Pistons forward Stanley Johnson warms up before the game against the Raptors at Air Canada Centre. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Raptors guard DeMar DeRozan scores against the Pistons during the first half in Toronto on Sunday, Feb.12, 2017. Frank Gunn, AP Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
The Pistons’ bench did the heavy lifting with 52 points on a night starters Jon Leuer and Reggie Jackson didn’t have anything. 
Tobias Harris led the Pistons with 24 points (9-for-13 shooting), with Ish Smith adding 15 points (6-for-10 shooting), five assists and five rebounds. Smith and Harris both went in the game at the 7:19 mark of the third quarter and never left the floor. 
“That unit obviously struggled, but the reason Reggie and Jon didn’t come back was not because they didn’t deserve another chance at it, even though they played bad,” Van Gundy said. “Tobias was playing really, really well and Ish was playing really, really well.” 
The Pistons climbed back in the game with a 16-6 run to open the fourth quarter – a quarter where the Pistons would eventually outscore the Raptors, 36-19. The Pistons shot 62% in the fourth quarter. 
But the Raptors (32-23) looked safe when Kyle Lowry’s lay-up with 1:23 left gave them a 101-96 lead. 
A Drummond free throw after an offensive rebound and a Caldwell-Pope jumper cut the deficit to two with 47 seconds remaining. 
After Lowry missed a short jumper, Smith rushed into the frontcourt with Van Gundy declining to get a time-out. 
Smith drove into the lane and then found Caldwell-Pope open in the corner. 
Swish! — Detroit Pistons (@DetroitPistons) February 13, 2017 
“Just hope it goes in, that’s what I was thinking,” Caldwell-Pope said. “I know I had a rough night shooting the basketball from the field and three. 
“Every time I came out of the huddle, even at halftime, everybody was like, ‘Keep shooting, keep shooting.’ Don’t let it get me down. I kept shooting and it had to be the game-winning shot that I hit.” 
Caldwell-Pope finished with 21 points on 8-for-22 shooting. 
“I envy those guys, whether they’re missing or making, they have the confidence to take the next shot,” Smith said. “For me, when I miss a couple, I start thinking, ‘Alright, maybe this not a good shot.’ Those guys have supreme confidence.” 
Smith thought about taking the shot, but, with the Raptors discombobulated, saw Lowry was forced to guard two guys and made the pass to Caldwell-Pope. 
“Just make the right play and kick it to the guy in the corner,” Smith said. “Pope, he kept shooting with confidence. All his shots were looking good. I wasn’t worried about it. I was going to keep finding him. He hit the big one when it counted.” 
After a Raptors time-out, Morris had to face DeRozan one-on-one. 
DeRozan missed the shot just before the buzzer, and the Pistons have now won eight of their past 13 games. DeMar DeRozan goes off on official after missing game-winning shot attempt. pic.twitter.com/TjMTvwIGrZ — The Crossover (@TheCrossover) February 13, 2017 
DeRozan led the Raptors with 26 points (10-for-21 shooting). Lowry finished 15 points, and Jonas Valanciunas added 17 points and nine rebounds for the Raptors. 
Similar to the season opener against Toronto, Drummond picked up two early fouls. 
DeRozan started off hot, scoring 10 points in the first quarter to give the Raptors a 27-25 lead. 
The Pistons' bench fueled an 11-5 run to start the second quarter and took a 37-32 lead. 
But the Raptors surged the moment Van Gundy started bringing back starters. 
The Raptors went on a 19-2 run to take a 51-39 lead. 
Van Gundy went back to Harris, Stanley Johnson (11 points), Smith and Aron Baynes and closed the half on a 6-0 run to cut the deficit to 51-45. 
The Pistons' starters were still sluggish to start the second half, and the Pistons quickly found themselves down 16 midway through the third quarter. 
The Raptors eventually took an 82-66 lead into the fourth quarter.
